value: Afterward Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh and said, âThis is what the
, the God of Israel, says: âLet my people go, so that they may hold a festival to me in the wilderness.âââ
Pharaoh said, âWho is the
, that I should obey him and let Israel go? I do not know the
and I will not let Israel go.â
Then they said, âThe God of the Hebrews has met with us. Now let us take a three-day journey into the wilderness to offer sacrifices to the
our God, or he may strike us with plagues or with the sword.â
But the king of Egypt said, âMoses and Aaron, why are you taking the people away from their labor? Get back to your work!â
Then Pharaoh said, âLook, the people of the land are now numerous, and you are stopping them from working.â
That same day Pharaoh gave this order to the slave drivers and overseers in charge of the people:
âYou are no longer to supply the people with straw for making bricks; let them go and gather their own straw.
But require them to make the same number of bricks as before; donât reduce the quota. They are lazy; that is why they are crying out, âLet us go and sacrifice to our God.â
Make the work harder for the people so that they keep working and pay no attention to lies.â
Then the slave drivers and the overseers went out and said to the people, âThis is what Pharaoh says: âI will not give you any more straw.
Go and get your own straw wherever you can find it, but your work will not be reduced at all.âââ
So the people scattered all over Egypt to gather stubble to use for straw.
The slave drivers kept pressing them, saying, âComplete the work required of you for each day, just as when you had straw.â
And Pharaohâs slave drivers beat the Israelite overseers they had appointed, demanding, âWhy havenât you met your quota of bricks yesterday or today, as before?â
Then the Israelite overseers went and appealed to Pharaoh: âWhy have you treated your servants this way?
Your servants are given no straw, yet we are told, âMake bricks!â Your servants are being beaten, but the fault is with your own people.â
Pharaoh said, âLazy, thatâs what you areâlazy! That is why you keep saying, âLet us go and sacrifice to the
Now get to work. You will not be given any straw, yet you must produce your full quota of bricks.â
The Israelite overseers realized they were in trouble when they were told, âYou are not to reduce the number of bricks required of you for each day.â
When they left Pharaoh, they found Moses and Aaron waiting to meet them,
and they said, âMay the
look on you and judge you! You have made us obnoxious to Pharaoh and his officials and have put a sword in their hand to kill us.â
Moses returned to the
and said, âWhy, Lord, why have you brought trouble on this people? Is this why you sent me?
Ever since I went to Pharaoh to speak in your name, he has brought trouble on this people, and you have not rescued your people at all.â
